div1.p: Hench enjoys the second draft of Truby's manuscript.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Jefferson Randolph Kean, October 1, 1941
div1.p:
I am busy trying to finish our Rheumatism Review, which occupies almost
every spare moment. Therefore, I am late in answering your last letter (I am also
again tardy in answering General Truby!). Let me first answer your letter of Sep-
tember 19.

Thank you very much for getting me straight on the whereabouts of Dr.
Henry Rose Carter. I am much disturbed about your request for me to return the
original print of your portrait still hanging in Havana. You say that Mrs. Kean
does not believe I returned it in the little steel box with the diary. I hate
very much to disagree with her but I remember your telling me when you sent it to
me that she had rather regreted your removing it from the safe in your home, and I
was particularly careful of it. I am as positive as one can be that I returned it
in the little box in a regular, small sized buff colored envelope. I distinctly
remember checking that over a couple of times before mailing it. In the envelope
were not only the original but also a copy of the original which I had had made here.
I have made it a policy when copying photographs loaned to me not only to return the
original but to return a copy as an expression of my appreciation and so that the
lender might hereafter not have to send out an original for further requests. It
disturbs me greatly that you cannot lay your hands on this. I hate to ask you to
look through your desk again but I am practically positive that you will find it.
Perhaps it was stuck in the diary itself. However, even if you can't find it, the
loss may not be too great as I have the film which is practically as good as your
C 81740 own. It is listed in our Mayo Clinic photographic file as c81740, so that you and
your relatives can always find it here and have copies made. I am sending not a
very good copy of this print but just to refresh your memory. If you really cannot
find your original I shall be very glad to have a nice enlargement of this photograph
made on special paper and send it to you with my sincerest regrets and best wishes.
To fortify myself I reviewed my correspondence as of the time I sent you the box
with the diary and photographs. At that time, my correspondence says that I also
returned two reprints you loaned me and four photostatic copies of pages from your
diary. These were all sent together and later you returned to me the photostatic
copies of the diary with some corrections in your own handwriting. These were re-
ceived at your home while you were in Richmond. They were sent about October 21, 1940.
You were unable to acknowledge their receipt until your letter of November 27 as you
had been away and on your return were ill for a few days.

I am so pleased with the little snapshot I took of you and General
Ireland that I am sending you by separate post one for you to keep, one for General
Ireland to keep and one which I shall be very proud to have returned to me with the
signatures of yourself and General Ireland. In order to save you bother after your
autograph it, I am enclosing two labels, one which you can use to send it to General
Ireland and one which he in turn can use to return the photograph to me. I will be
very proud to have this.

Just yesterday I received the second draft of General Truby's autobio-
graphy. What a tremendous improvement it is on the first one. I had a rather bad
cold with a sinusitis and was feeling rather weary. I picked it up at 10 P.M. to
General J. R. Kean - 2 - October 1, 1941
read a few pages. It was so fascinating that I read it all, finishing it at a
quarter of 3 A.M., amid the scoldings of my wife! I have made a few suggestions
for corrections and I think have been able to give him a couple of dates that he
wanted: the approximate date of the visit of Durham and Myers as given in one of
Reed's letters to his wife. I sincerely hope that his manuscript can be published
by the Surgeon General's office. I don't know that they publish such things but
it simply must not be lost. It should be printed even if it has to be privately
printed and I for one will be glad to make a contribution to see that it is published.

Now for your letter of September 26. I will send to General Truby rather
than to you the items which you sent to me. I am having them copied and they should
go to General Truby this week. I was able to get a copy of the Military Surgeon
which has General Winter's article in it.

I have had a couple of very appreciative letters from Miss Wood and so
far as correspondence is concerned she seems to be a very nice woman.

I am also sending you by separate post, a copy of Hygeia, with my yellow
fever article in it. Shortly I will have a voluminous number of reprints and will
be glad to send you any number you wish, even as many as twenty or twenty-five.
div1.closer: Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
